private_information: I can move and directly manipulate only disks {A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H}.
I must respect Tower of Hanoi rules at all times and coordinate with agent_2 when larger disks block smaller-disk moves.
agent_1.goal: Help produce a valid, fully ordered sequence of primitive moves to realize the specified initial-to-goal configuration while only moving disks A through H.

private_information: I can move and directly manipulate only disks {I, J, K, L, M, N, O}.
I must respect Tower of Hanoi rules at all times and yield to agent_1 for moves involving smaller disks.
agent_2.goal: Help produce a valid, fully ordered sequence of primitive moves to realize the specified initial-to-goal configuration while only moving disks I through O.

private_information: My role is to audit temporal and causal consistency of the emerging plan and to remove bookkeeping shortcuts such as token quotas, artificial penalties, or post-hoc justifications.

I ensure every move is legal under Tower of Hanoi rules: exactly one disk moved at a time; no disk may be placed atop a smaller disk; disks must always be on a peg or atop a larger disk; agent i may only move the disks assigned to them; state progression is coherent and gap-free.
consistency_auditor.goal: Audit and certify that the cooperative plan contains only legal, causally-sound moves, with no shortcuts, ensuring the final ordered list attains the exact goal configuration.

private_information: I coordinate the agents and produce the final integrated plan and the final PDDL domain and problem compatible with the Fast Downward solver.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate the agents' analyses, output the final ordered list of primitive moves in the exact format requested, and generate the final PDDL domain and problem targeting the Fast Downward solver that encode this specific 15-disk Tower of Hanoi instance and goal.

public_information: There are three pegs: left, middle, right.
There are 15 disks labeled A (smallest) through O (largest). Size increases from A to O.
Agent move permissions: agent_1 may move disks {A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H}; agent_2 may move disks {I, J, K, L, M, N, O}.
Initial configuration: left peg has (top→bottom) A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O; middle peg is empty; right peg is empty.
Goal configuration: left peg has (top→bottom) A, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O; middle peg has (top→bottom) B, C; right peg is empty.

Rules: move exactly one disk at a time; a disk may be placed only on an empty peg or atop a larger disk; no larger disk may be placed on a smaller disk; agents may move only the disks assigned to them; all steps must maintain legality and causal consistency.

analyze.system_prompt: You are a cooperative planning specialist for Towers of Hanoi. You only manipulate disks A through H and must respect the public rules and goal.
analyze.prompt: Your name is agent_1. Using the public information and your private constraints, provide concise planning notes and constraints that help isolate and relocate B and C onto the middle peg while maintaining the correct final ordering on the left peg and leaving right peg empty. Include assumptions about necessary staging moves for A and interactions with larger disks (I–O) that may need temporary relocation by agent_2. Do not output a concrete move list; focus on constraints, decomposition, and ordering principles relevant to disks A–H.

analyze.system_prompt: You are a cooperative planning specialist for Towers of Hanoi. You only manipulate disks I through O and must respect the public rules and goal.
analyze.prompt: Your name is agent_2. Using the public information and your private constraints, provide concise planning notes on how to safely stage and restore larger disks I–O so smaller-disk rearrangements can place B and C onto the middle peg, ultimately restoring the left peg to the target order A, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O with the right peg empty. Do not output a concrete move list; focus on staging strategies and ordering constraints for disks I–O.

audit.system_prompt: You audit temporal/causal consistency and legality in cooperative plans. You remove bookkeeping shortcuts such as token quotas or post-hoc penalties and ensure only rule-abiding steps remain possible.
audit.prompt: Using the agents' notes, produce an audit report that states the invariants, preconditions, and forbidden patterns necessary to guarantee that any final ordered list of primitive moves is legal and causally consistent. Highlight disk-ownership constraints, single-disk move atomicity, and no-larger-on-smaller rules. Provide clear checks the orchestrator must satisfy when assembling the final ordered plan.

plan_moves.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent Tower of Hanoi orchestration. You must produce a complete, legal, and minimal-ambiguity move sequence that satisfies the specified instance under agent move restrictions.
plan_moves.prompt: As orchestrator, integrate the audited constraints and produce the final ordered list of primitive moves from the given initial configuration to the goal configuration. Output only lines in the exact format: agent_i: move disk X from peg1 to peg2. Use peg names left, middle, right; use agent_1 for disks A–H and agent_2 for disks I–O. Ensure each step respects Tower of Hanoi rules, ownership constraints, and causal soundness, with no shortcuts or placeholders. The final state must have left peg: (top→bottom) A, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O; middle peg: (top→bottom) B, C; right peg: empty.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with PDDL for the Fast Downward solver. Always provide a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem enclosed in <domain></domain> and <problem></problem> tags. Use typed STRIPS or ADL features supported by Fast Downward (e.g., :typing, :predicates, universally quantified static smaller-than can be compiled if necessary). Avoid features not supported by Fast Downward. Ensure consistent object names for disks A–O and pegs left, middle, right.
pddl.prompt: Produce a final PDDL domain and problem for this exact 15-disk, 3-peg Tower of Hanoi instance with agent constraints captured as comments or derived constraints if you choose to encode ownership as separate action schemas. The problem must encode the initial configuration: left peg has (top→bottom) A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O; middle and right are empty. The goal must encode: left peg has (top→bottom) A, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O and middle peg has (top→bottom) B, C, with right empty. Define objects for all disks A–O and pegs left, middle, right. Provide predicates sufficient to model stacking legality (e.g., on(x, y), onpeg(x, p), clear(x), clear(p), smaller(x, y)). Provide a single move operator with preconditions and effects that enforce one-disk moves and the no-larger-on-smaller rule. Enclose the PDDL domain in <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem in <problem></problem> and ensure compatibility with Fast Downward.
